p: Phytophthora ramorum has been shown to be sensitive to drought, as highlighted by studies showing that free sporangia and chlamydospores were killed by drying at 30% relative humidity at room temperature for 30 minutes [57] and relative humidity below 50% significantly affected growth and germ tube elongation of zoospores [58]. However, sporangia have been recorded to survive up to six hours in moisture free conditions [52] and studies indicate that the pathogen can survive temperature and moisture stresses much more effectively within infected plant tissue [46]. Dry stress parameters were altered to begin accumulating below the lower soil moisture threshold for growth (SM0 = 0.2). The dry stress accumulation rate (HDS = −0.005 week −1) was selected to reflect the pathogen’s apparent sensitivity to drought.
